segments.text: out with a diagram that the support material for the course would be made up of several different disciplines and if they had two out of the six that was usually adequate and that they shouldn't be shouldn't have difficulty catching up on the others but that if they had more than two out of the six they would
probably find it much easier.
Describe the course and its makeup.
You taught it how many times per year?
This course is taught every fall semester.
And about how many normally in their first years?
How many students?
The student numbers, usually 10 or 12.
It was usually larger than some of our other graduate courses.

But it changed through the years because each of these areas are influenced by economic factors and when the geologists were getting more jobs, well the students went out in the field and that type of factor entered in.
It's a course that combines crystallography and mineralogy and chemistry and physics looking at the
at the solid materials of soils.
And that means everything from glass out of a volcano to the oldest, rustiest soils you can think of in the most highly weathered landscapes in the world.
Compare the course content then, 30 years ago, and now.
How has it changed?
It's changed mostly in exactness.
We used to make generalizations where the data were inadequate.
We would say in early textbooks you would find people writing about amorphous iron oxides
Well, amorphous iron oxides were really not amorphous, most always, but we didn't have electron microscopes that were good enough to identify those very tiny crystals with very small spacings.
And so today, that word amorphous has gotten smaller and smaller through the
through the decades.
And in general, we've gotten much more exact.
We can deal with bonding somewhat, chemical bonding with infrared more than we used to.
And the data set has expanded so much.
Some of the basics, of course, Roentgen invented, discovered x-rays about 100 years ago.
And that put clay mineralogy in, which is much of soil mineralogy.
And so we've had x-ray machines.
I use an x-ray machine that's 30 years old.
So in a sense, but with the computers and with the visuals,
Many of them now, of course, we do in color and do electronically and all that.
Those are technological advances.
Did this course, when you started it here, did it meet once a week, three times a week, seminar, lecture, or what?
Through the years, it's a heavy laboratory course because we teach several different instrumental methods, chemical methods, and physical methods.
So the students work very hard in the lab.
And usually we, starting in the early days, we had three lectures a week and we had two laboratory sessions.
Later in the term, we might narrow it down to one laboratory session.
But they spent a lot of extra hours in the laboratory just because we couldn't figure out any way to do the job more efficiently.
A couple of years ago, or more than that, some years ago, five years or so ago, I decided we're now on the west campus.
Many of these students come back and forth to the building.
And I thought it would be better if we get those students in and teach them all in two afternoons a week.
And that's the way we do it now.
We teach them a lecture, have a long lecture, then we have a break, and then we have a laboratory from two to five.
And that is better for the students and for the faculty.
So I like that.
Of course, we don't just use instruments in our laboratories.
We also use instruments in the electron mic laboratory.
Compare the facilities in the old state chemist building.
Did you all go straight over west of the track?
Compare that and that.
Well, it's a lot of overlap.
The centrifuges that we bought years before I came even, we're still using some of those.
And the x-ray machine that Kunze bought, I'm still using it.
But we computerized that, oh, 15 years ago or something.
And now, instead of having...
strip charts and such.
We have, all of our data comes out on a disk and we move it around electronically and plot it as we want to electronically.
In other words, we get a lot more out of the instrument because the computer
can run the instrument for us and help us to get the data in a manageable form.
And that's been a tremendous asset.
We saved $100,000 on the instrument simply by buying a computer and some data.

processing equipment that's made in a research laboratory in california by a small firm out there and and and now when we were working for example with the rice land poorly crystalline materials we just set the computer up to run that instrument for 10 hours if that's what it needed and and this is random particle statistics that we use

in case of x-rays, and therefore if we can integrate over 10 hours data sort of step by step, then our statistics are much better and we can get definitive data on things that we had never even found before.
Does each student have the same research task plus a special project?
Like in history, they'd do a term paper and it'd be a different term paper for each youngster.
What would be their laboratory research project?
In our case, each student is encouraged and they very, very consistently follow through, bring a sample from their thesis or dissertation research and we take it apart.
If it's a rock,

they grind it up and we pursue it if it's a soil clay that's wet or dry well we we deal with that or any soil uh of course most all of our procedures are directed toward soils because that's that's the main thrust of the course
And so they, this is a wonderful course, I think, and I think the students do too, in spite of the fact they work so long, they never really complain about the lab.
We take the soil apart, physically and chemically.
and then we analyze these components.

And then we put those data back together again, and they interpret those data in terms of if it's from two miles deep in an oil well, or if it's from the surface soil in a rice paddy, or it's from anywhere, any type of sample.
And if it's a treated material they're making for roadbed, that sort of thing.

So the students work on their own material, and I've served on many committees in geology and civil engineering, and the only mineralogy data that many of those students had in their thesis was what they got in our class.
Now, what we do now, and we've done in the last months, like from oceanography, they have a lot of fine equipment, but they don't have what we have.
So they send their student over, Bill Bryant, for example,
And we had this young lady from Italy who is a student of his.
She spent like two or three months taking the soils, the sediments from the Gulf apart and then X-raying them and so on and making the analyses.
And then that basis, she was writing her dissertation.
So that's one of the beauties of it.
It's an interactive course that goes on for quite some time, often.
But back to this comparing, in terms of the laboratory
equipment and space per student in the old and new buildings.
How did those compare?
We have a very adequate laboratory space.
Now we have shrunk through the years.
There was a time when we kept these students in the course separate from our own research laboratories.
We can't afford that luxury anymore.
So we now teach them in our research laboratories and we
teach them also to respect what's going on otherwise in the laboratory.
And this has worked out very well.
We fabricate a significant amount of our equipment and modify quite a lot of our equipment so we don't have showy laboratories.
but they're very functional.
We use a magnet to separate the iron minerals from the other minerals.
This was a cast off from chemistry that I traded an old spectrometer for that I couldn't use anymore.
And yet this magnet has served us very well.
That's the kind of things we sometimes do.
Now, when you got here, did you feel that the students you had here, that their capability was as good as what you had known at the other two schools, or better, or what?
I think the first student I had had a little problem in that
we were sort of emerging from one type of research to more modern research.
And he struggled quite a bit.
And of course, he was changing from one advisor to another.
That didn't make it any easier.
But he ended up finishing here, doing a post-doctoral in Louisiana, and then going back and being a leader in India.
And I even visited him there.
So he...
Against odds, he was not the most brilliant and effective student we ever had.
But he had a lot of thrust, and it all turned out very well.
But in general, those students that were in your course?
We had good students.
We've had good students throughout.
This is a complex mix, as I've said.
Not only of professions, but ethnically it's complex.
I presume you had fewer international students 30 years ago.
Definitely so, yeah.
Were most of the American?
No, and there weren't any girls in those first days either.
But now my course is probably a third girls, young ladies.
Do you remember any events that had anything to do with the first girls in the courses?
Were there any awkward moments or amusing moments?
How did the other students relate to the young ladies?
I think at times we rather soft-pedaled around the young ladies because we weren't quite sure how that was going to work out.
But there's so many surprises in students.
We had a case a few years ago when we had a little Chinese girl, didn't say very much, and very attentive.
And then later when she was writing, we realized that she was a perfectionist in English.
And she had actually grown up in New York.
And then we would talk to her freely and it was a revelation, you know.
She was really a very exceptional student.
And then we've had some others who just got here and they really struggled because the English wasn't... One thing that I learned, the English taught in Taiwan
is unfortunately not very good.

The only student that I had from Taiwan who had excellent English served in their military, as an officer in the military, and he had had a lot of exposure of English, and that was Tsai Chin, who got his master's here, his doctor's here, both under my advice, and now he is an executive in the environmental branch of the industry in Taiwan.
He started with humble beginnings with no support, but he eventually, and he's been back here to visit us from time to time.
In general, I'm not going to ask the negative, in general, the best international students come from what country and or areas of the world?
The best that you've had.
Pretty hard question to answer in view of the diversity of them.
The student I have right now from China, mainland China, is one of the best I've ever had.
And partly because he developed his English very well, and he had his sights.
I have corresponded with him for seven years, and he's been here four years.
So he prepared himself for this.
And the Taiwanese student who did well, he came from zero.
It's very slow to emerge, but in the end was quite good.
So, you know, we don't have a very good sampling of students from Germany and Britain.
And so it's, I would say,
the Chinese students would be one of the better groups.
Now, in the department as a whole, we've had people from more other disciplines and different other countries, Scandinavia and so on.
But it's a complex subject and
And I try to examine students in such a way that I cut across what they learn.
And therefore, by the end of the term, I have a whole page of data on what their performance is.
And they don't spread out as much as it would be in some other grading systems.
And therefore,
Well, I've had some excellent students from the USA that certainly did better than others, but they had more going for them, I think.
What has been your philosophy about grading?
Did you grade on a curve, or?
I grade on a curve, and I grade, and students have taught me something about grading, too.
I didn't used to give much of the grade for lab, because it's so hard to grade laboratory.
But one of the students,
pointed that out to me once, so I then changed it.
I developed a more formal, structured grading system and a lab manual, put it in there along with all the other course materials.
I grade on the curve.
I grade a small percentage for daily work.
mainly just to stimulate their activity.
usually have three major exams and then two grades in the laboratory at least.
One would be their final report.

They submit reports on certain of the instruments and the work they did with them, but their final report is really kind of a mini research paper on their sample and what they learned about it and what they learned from the scientific literature about it.
and how that applies.
You said you had 10, 12 normally in the course.
Does grading on the curve imply only a certain number are going to get an A and a certain number are going to flunk?
No.
It's such a diverse population.
I normally gave As and Bs and maybe one C occasionally.
That's pretty much the grade.
And if I had graded them just on the written exams, for example, well, I would have probably had a wider distribution.
But when you put together the
recitation on an exam along with a laboratory report.
Some people do a much, the engineers write great reports because they're trained to do that.
And so those things tend to balance out so the students get closer together as the course gets on further.
And let's face it, that's a basic course for their thesis research and
I was really mostly concerned that they'd be able to do the work properly.
If I thought that they could not interpret an X-ray diffraction pattern and tell what the crystal phases were that were there, then they wouldn't get a B in the course, or an A, certainly.
In fact, do you work the students harder now than you did 30 years ago?
Does the course require more effort?
We try not to do that because it is a heavy course.
I think what we do is we give them more service and they go further.
That's the way I see it.
And I have a research associate who works with me in the course.
And with the advent of the computer and all the efficiencies that that brings,
We go much further with more methods, and they're better trained than they used to be.
Now, in recent years, these two days where the course meets and the inaudibles are, what day?
Tuesday, Thursday.
Tuesday and Thursday.
And it's from what hour to what hour?
The lecture is 12.
Let's see, 1245 to, when I'm doing it, I get used to it, but it's odd.
It's a 75-minute lecture, overlaps part of the noon hour, and then we have a 15-minute break, as I remember, and then I believe it's at 2 o'clock when we start the lab.
And it goes till?
Till 5, 10, according to the clock.
In a normal day, what time would you leave after lab, though?
Or you're here till about what?
Well, I would be here till five, and usually a little later, but my lab is mostly taught by my research associate, and he would definitely be here.
And in what setting do you do the lecture?
Is it in a seminar room around a table, or?
I like the open forum room.
Actually, the room I use is a room that my colleague
Tom Hallmark uses to teach soil morphology.
I chose it because we have these tables, and the students can sit close.
I use a lot of models and a lot of visuals, so the surface is all bare, and I don't have a lectern sitting in front of me.
I use an overhead projector some.

And along the walls, they have soil profiles from Texas and Hawaii and some other states and special soil maps, the periodic table of the elements, and some maps to show different soil regions, the taxonomy of the soils, which
This being a graduate course, we use quite a bit of soil science, but we don't have all soil science students.
So therefore, I have to have some visuals that they can just pick up all by looking up on the ceiling there.
And there are specimens lying around in there that occasionally I use in addition to the ones that I take in.
There's a little indoctrination there, I guess you could say.
The taxonomy of soils is kind of like the taxonomy of plants.
It's familiar to people who use it, but not very familiar to the public.
And then soil taxonomy is based on analytical data to a very significant extent.
So to keep from burdening the student with more taxonomy than they want, I use that display of soils.
Otherwise, when I said you notice the color of the iron oxides in this soil,
they wouldn't have a visual image at all.
And these profiles are one meter high or so.
Now almost every student in there is there very much by their choice because of their thesis or dissertation.
Did the course, the official title is of the course?
I think it's just called Soil Mineralogy.
Does it have a nickname?
Do the students, have they come up with anything?
Probably they have some that I haven't ever heard about.
It's called clay mineralogy or soil mineralogy, depending on who you ask.
And it's a heavily instrumented course.
I don't know if they've ever coined an expression for it or not.
Do you remember any kinds of pranks or jokes?
in the lab or anything they've ever done for fun?
They're pretty busy.
They probably have, but I don't really recall any of them.
What about something going wrong?
Oh, well, as they go in the room the first day, we have a big centrifuge cover.
with much of the paint scoured off of it.
And a note under, this is an object lesson.
You always check the cover on the centrifuge before you turn it on, because someone failed to do that once, and that cost us a lot.
And centrifuges are, you know, they're kind of the workhorse of this lab, and they're really not
serious threats to anyone, but they have tremendous power.
And they're like these automobile tires that have fallen apart.
At the speeds they run, they're dangerous if not used correctly.
And so we spend a little time on that, and we've used centrifuges with just a few minor cases like that.
We occasionally have an accident, but not very often.
What other cautionary advice do you give the class?
Chemicals.
We deal with hydrogen peroxide, which is much more concentrated than bleach for the hair.
And we deal with some solvents occasionally.
Through the years, we have put aside most of the toxic things that we used to use.
We don't use benzene anymore.
We used to use benzene, think much about it.
We used to use alcohol and acetone quite a lot.
We've largely put those aside.
Substituted other things.
Let's see.
Was there a significant early graduate student, one that you particular, in your earliest years, you now look back on with great pride?
Oh yes, yes.
I would say,
More than one.
Well, describe some of those.
One of those students.
I had a professor from Colorado State University who wanted to come down for, as I recall, one term.
He was still on the faculty there.
He came and spent his term, and he was not so special.
But then he went back home and he sent me a graduate student of his named Doug Ming.
M-I-N-G?
Ming.
M-I-N-G.
It's not oriental.
It's probably a shortening of the German, I imagine.
And Doug had been a soils consultant on summers and he had been an athlete in Colorado State as well as a soils student.
Gotten his master's degree with his
gentleman who had been here briefly.
And we had a, he was a kind of student that you didn't have to give much instruction to, we just kind of discussed things on an even level.
And from time to time out on the atrium we would stop and talk in the morning about what he might work on.
He was taking a lot of courses.
And finally, we concluded that he ought to work on zeolites.
And the reasons that we had was that nobody really knew anything about zeolites in soils, because they don't occur in many soils.
And they are being sold to the ranchers and farmers down in the valley.
And we knew that there were some in those soils from the geology information that was available.
Well, in the end, Doug, as he went on, once he got motivated, well,

he did several things uh he did his literature review as we start things and i was doing the second of our three books and i said well doug would you like to do that as a as a chapter in the book and you could get publication of your of your review and so he liked that idea so i asked
colleague from New York who is a zeolite professional in a geologist sense.
to team with him, and they wrote that.
And as he got further along, he began to say, well, nobody uses zeolites much in soils.
I don't know whether I'm going to be able to get a job or not.
And it was the kind of time when jobs weren't so abundant.
And then one day, he got a call from this geologist, Mumpton, and said, would you like to come and give a paper on your dissertation?
to an international meeting.
He's going to meet in one of the Eastern Bloc countries.
And Doug said, well, I'd like to do that, but I'm writing my dissertation, and I don't have any money to go over there.
And so they just kept upping the ante.
And finally they said, all right, we'll pay you away.
You're the only person we've been able to find who can address zeolites in soils with the experience base that you have.
He had gone down in southwest Texas and studied them in the field, and we had gone down there and sampled and so on.
So he'd gotten quite a bit of experience.
So he went and gave a paper, which was published, and along with several others.
And then he got a postdoctoral, yes, with NASA.
And then after a while, well, he just stayed and stayed.
And they made a position for him.
He's now a space scientist.
And they developed two systems to support man for long journeys in space.
And one of them is called Zeoponics.
And that grew out of Doug Ming's dissertation.
Of course, it's come a long way, but that's what got him started.
And I remember distinctly him coming one night.
I was working in the Electron Night Center alone, and he came in and said, Dr. Dixon, I'm thinking about dropping out of school and going back and consulting like I used to this summer.
What do you think about that?
I said, well, Doug, you see what I'm doing and when I'm doing it, so that's all the way I feel about you.
If you give this your best, you'll get a job.
We don't know where it's going to be, but you'll get a job.
And so he never asked that question anymore.
And now he's
He organizes sessions and national scientific meetings, and he travels all over the country speaking for NASA, promoting their programs, and he has a research program there.
Done exceptionally well.
So you're obviously proud of him.
Others you want to mention?
